[[File:Kencf0618FacebookNetwork.jpg|thumb|A [[Graph drawing|social network diagram]] displaying tribes [[Cluster analysis|clustered]] by friendship ties among a set of [[Facebook]] users]]
The term '''tribe''' or '''digital tribe'''<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|title = Digital Tribes - Creating Behaviour Change in Users - The UX Review|url = http://theuxreview.co.uk/digital-tribes-creating-behaviour-change-users/|website = The UX Review|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> is used as a [[slang]] term for an unofficial [[community]] of people who share a common interest, and usually who are loosely affiliated with each other through [[social media]] or other [[Internet]] <nowiki/>mechanisms. The term is related to "''[[tribe]]''", which traditionally refers to people closely associated in both [[geography]] and [[genealogy]].<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|title = Tribes and Tribal: Origin, Use, and Future of the Concept|url = https://www.researchgate.net/publication/260405121_Tribes_and_Tribal_Origin_Use_and_Future_of_the_Concept|website = ResearchGate|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> Nowadays, it looks more like a [[virtual community]] or a personal network and it is often called global digital tribe. Most [[anthropologist]]s agree that a tribe is a (small) [[society]] that practices its own customs and [[culture]], and that these define the tribe. The tribes are divided into [[clan]]s, with their own customs and [[cultural values]] that differentiate them from activities that occur in 'real life' contexts. People feel more inclined to share and defend their [[idea]]s on [[social network]]s than they would dare to say to someone face to face. For example, it would be ridiculous to '[[Poke (Facebook)|poke]]' someone in real life.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|title = Learning with 'e's: Global digital tribe|url = http://steve-wheeler.blogspot.co.uk/2013/05/global-digital-tribe.html|website = steve-wheeler.blogspot.co.uk|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref>
== History == The term "[[tribe]]" originated around the time of the [[Ancient Greece|Greek]] city-states and the early formation of the [[Roman Empire]]. The [[Latin]] term "tribus" has since been transformed to mean "''A group of persons forming a [[community]] and claiming descent from a common [[ancestor]]''" (Oxford English Dictionary, IX, 1933, p. 339, as cited in Fried, 1975, p. 7). As years passed by, the range of meanings have grown greater, for example, "''Any of various systems of [[social organization]] comprising several local [[village]]s, [[Tribe (Native American)|band]]s, [[districts]], lineages, or other groups and sharing a common [[Ancestor|ancestry]], [[language]], [[culture]], and [[name]]''" (Morris, 1980, p. 1369). Morris (1980) also notes that a [[tribe]] is a "''group of persons with a common occupation, interest, or [[habit]],''" and "''a large family.''"<ref name=":12" /> Vestiges of ancient tribe communities were preserved in both large gatherings (like [[football]] matches) and in small ones (like [[Church (building)|church]] [[Community|communities]]). Even though nowadays the range of groups referred to as tribal is truly enormous, it wasn't until the [[industrial society]] eroded the tribal gatherings of more primitive societies and redefined [[community]]. However, the existence of [[social media]] as we know it today is due to the [[post-industrial society]] that has seen the rapid growth of [[personal computer]]s, [[mobile phone]]s and [[Internet|the Internet]]. People now can [[Collaboration|collaborate]], [[Communication|communicate]], celebrate, commemorate, give their advice and share their ideas around these virtual clans that have once again redefined the [[Social behavior|social behaviour]].<ref name=":13" />
The first attempt of such social [[Community|communities]] dates back to at least 2003, when [[tribe.net]] was launched.
=== tribe.net starting point === Tribe Networks is the driving force behind [[tribe.net]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = tribe.net|url = http://www.tribe.com/|website = tribe.net|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> which is a [[website]] similar to other [[Social networking websites|social networking]] sites. Users can create their own profiles and join networks, called 'tribes', based on common interests. Moreover, members can post job offers and event recommendations.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Why did tribe.net (Mark Pincus) not work out? - Quora|url = https://www.quora.com/Why-did-tribe.net-(Mark-Pincus)-not-work-out|website = www.quora.com|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> Tribe serves 50 metropolitan [[market (place)|market]]s, its largest being the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], [[Los Angeles metropolitan area|Los Angeles]], [[Washington, D.C.]], and [[New York City]]. The firm was found in July 2003 by [[Mark Pincus]], Paul Martino and Valerie Syme, with the goal of connecting local people for what Pincus described as "''an online cocktail party where people are getting leads through their friends. So people are there to have fun and connect and meet new people.''" Soon the site caught the attention of [[Knight Ridder]], The Washington Post Company and blue chip venture firm Mayfield, which both totally invested around $6.3 million in [[venture capital]]. After three months of activity, Tribe brought together 48,000 registered users and 6,900 distinct tribes, earning revenue from job postings and class fields.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title = Vault Guide to the Top Internet Industry Employers|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=OPjwN9_FmkYC|publisher = Vault Inc.|date = 2006-01-01|isbn = 9781581313840|first = Laurie|last = Pasiuk}}</ref>
== Tribes from a technical perspective == Not only do [[Twitter]] tribes have mutual interests,<ref name=":15">{{Cite web|title = The rise of the Twitter tribes|url = https://www.theguardian.com/music/2011/apr/02/twitter-tribes-lady-gaga-rihanna|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-11-01|first = Michael|last = Cragg}}</ref> but they also share potentially [[subconscious]] [[language]] features as found in the 2013 study by researchers from [[Royal Holloway University of London]] and [[Princeton University|Princeton]]. Dr. John Bryden from the School of Biological Sciences at Royal Holloway states that it is possible to anticipate which community somebody is likely to belong to,<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|title = Which Twitter tribe are you? Researchers discover new wave of online communities which even have their own languages|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2293912/Twitters-online-tribes-revealed-Users-forming-distinct-communities-languages-study-shows.html|website = Mail Online|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> with up to 80 percent accuracy. This research shows that people try to join [[Society|societies]] based on the same interests and [[Hobby|hobbies]]. In order to achieve this, publicly available messages were sent via Twitter to record conversations between two or more participants. As a result, each community can be characterised by their most used words. This approach can enrich new communities detection based on word analysis in order to automatically classify people inside [[social network]]s. The methods of identification of tribes relied heavily on [[algorithm]]s and techniques from [[statistical physics]], [[computational biology]] and [[network science]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Word usage mirrors community structure in the online social network Twitter|url = http://www.epjdatascience.com/content/2/1/3|journal = EPJ Data Science|date = 2013-02-25|issn = 2193-1127|pages = 3|volume = 2|issue = 1|doi = 10.1140/epjds15|first = John|last = Bryden|first2 = Sebastian|last2 = Funk|first3 = Vincent AA|last3 = Jansen}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite web|title = Twitter users forming tribes with own language, tweet analysis shows|url = https://www.theguardian.com/news/datablog/2013/mar/15/twitter-users-tribes-language-analysis-tweets|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-10-31|first = Jason|last = Rodrigues}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite web|title = People with same interests or occupation form 'tribes' on Twitter {{!}} Latest News & Updates at Daily News & Analysis|url = http://www.dnaindia.com/scitech/report-people-with-same-interests-or-occupation-form-tribes-on-twitter-1811627|website = dna|accessdate = 2015-10-31}}</ref><ref name=":16">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ickn.org/documents/Tribefinder_COINs18.pdf|title=Identifying Tribes on Twitter through Shared Context|last=Gloor|first=P.|last2=Fronzetti Colladon|first2=A.|date=|website=ICKN Intelligent Collaborative Knowledge Networks|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-09-11|last3=de Oliveira|first3=J.|last4=Rovelli|first4=P.}}</ref>
A different approach is taken by Tribefinder.<ref name=":16" /> The system is able to identify tribal affiliations of [[Twitter]] users using [[deep learning]] and [[machine learning]].<ref name=":16" /> The system establishes to which tribes individuals belong through the analysis of their tweets and the comparison of their [[vocabulary]]. These tribal vocabularies are previously generated based on the vocabulary of tribal influencers and leaders using keywords expressing concepts, ideas and beliefs.
The final step to make the system learn on how to associate random individuals with specific tribes consists of the analysis of the language these influential tribal leaders use through deep learning. In so doing, classifiers are created using embedding and [[Long short-term memory|LSTM]] (long short-term memory) models. Specifically, these classifiers work by collecting the Twitter feeds of all the users from the tribes that Tribefinder is training on. On these, [[embedding]] is applied to map words into vectors, which are then used as input for the following LSTM models. Tribefinder analyzes the individual’s word usage in their tweets and then assigns the corresponding alternative realities, lifestyle, and recreation tribal affiliation based on the similarities with the specific tribal vocabularies.
== An in-depth look into the research == The research had four main stages on which it focused: background, results, conclusions and methods.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" />
=== Background === The [[language]] is a system of [[communication]] consisting of [[phoneme|sounds]], words, and [[grammar]], or the system of [[communication]] used by people in a particular [[country]] or type of work.<ref>{{Cite web|title = language Meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary|url = http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/language|website = dictionary.cambridge.org|accessdate = 2015-10-31}}</ref> Language is perhaps the most important characteristic that distinguishes human beings from other animals.<ref>Nowak, M.A, Jansen, V.A.A., and Plotkin, J.B 2000. [http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v404/n6777/abs/404495a0.html] Nature, 404, pp.495-498.</ref> In addition, it has a wide range of social implications that can be associated with [[Social group|social or cultural groups]]. People usually group in communities with the same interests. This will result in a variation of the words they use because of the differentiation of terms from each domain. Therefore, the [[Hypothesis of a theorem|hypothesis]] of this study would be that this variation should closely match the community structure of the [[Social network|network]]. To test this theory, around 250,000 users from the [[List of social networking websites|social networking]] and [[microblogging]] site Twitter were monitored in order to analyse whether the groups identified had the same language features or not. As Twitter uses unstructured data and users can send messages to any other users, the study had to be based on complex algorithms. These algorithms had to determine the word frequency inside messages between people and make a link to the groups they usually visited.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" />
=== Results and discussion === [[File:Word usage based tribes on Twitter, Bryden et al.png|thumb|517x517px|Communication between and within tribes of [[Twitter]] users [[Cluster analysis|clustered]] based on word usage. '''Tribes''' tend to communicate more within than between themselves.]] The problem of detecting the community features is one of the main issues in the study of networking systems. [[Social network]]s naturally tend to divide themselves into communities or [[modules]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|title = Modularity and community structure in networks|url = http://www.pnas.org/content/103/23/8577|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date = 2006-06-06|issn = 0027-8424|pmc = 1482622|pmid = 16723398|pages = 8577–8582|volume = 103|issue = 23|doi = 10.1073/pnas.0601602103|first = M. E. J.|last = Newman|arxiv = physics/0602124|bibcode = 2006PNAS..103.8577N}}</ref> However, some world networks are too big so they must be simplified before information can be extracted.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = mapequation.org - publications|url = http://www.mapequation.org/publications.html|website = www.mapequation.org|accessdate = 2015-10-31}}</ref> As a result, an effective way of dealing with this drawback for smaller communities is by using ''[[Modularity (programming)|modularity]]'' [[algorithm]]s in order to partition users into even smaller [[Social group|groups]].<ref name=":2" /> For larger ones, a more efficient algorithm called 'map equation' decomposes a [[Network topology|network]] into [[Modularity|modules]] by optimally compressing a description of information flows on the network.<ref name=":3" /> Each community was therefore characterised according to the words they used the most, based on a ranking algorithm. To determine the significance of word usage differences, word endings and word lengths were also measured and showed that the [[pattern]] found was the correct one. Moreover, these studies also helped in predicting community membership of users, by comparing their own word frequencies with community word usage. This helped in forecasting which community a certain user is going to access based on the words that they are using.<ref name=":1" /> [[File:Proportion of users whose community is correctly predicted.png|thumb|The proportion of users whose topological community association is correctly predicted by the study.|700x700px|none]]
=== Conclusions === [[File:An illustration of the method for predicting which community a user is embedded in.png|thumb|An illustration of the method for predicting which community a user is embedded in.|333x333px]] The aim of this research was to study the bond between community structure in a social network environment and language use within the community . The striking pattern that was found suggests that people from different clans tend to use different words based on their own interests and hobbies.<ref name=":4" /> This study can show how people make friends based on the same [[vocabulary]] range that they use.<ref name=":14" /> Even though this approach didn't manage to cover all people inside Twitter, it has several advantages over ordinary surveys that cover a smaller scale of groups: it is systematic, it is non-intrusive and it easily produces large volumes of rich [[data]]. Moreover, other cultural characteristics can be found out when extending this study. For example, whether individuals that belong to multiple communities use different word sets in each of them.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":0" />
=== Methods === A process called [[Snowball sampling|snowball-sampling]] helped forming the sample [[Network topology|network]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Word usage mirrors community structure in the online social network Twitter - Springer|url = https://link.springer.com/article/10.1140/epjds15/fulltext.html|doi = 10.1140/epjds15}}</ref> Each user's [[Twitter|tweets]] and messages were recorded and any new users referenced were added to a list from where they were picked to be sampled. Messages that were copies have been ignored. In order to find out the words that characterise each clan, the fraction of people that use a certain word was compared with the fraction of people that use that word globally. The difference between communities has also been measured by comparing the relative word usage frequency.<ref name=":1" /> Last but not least, individual word usage was compared with each community word usage to pick the best matching clan for individual users.<ref name=":14" />
== Different language misspellings within tribes == [[Word]]s, and the way we [[Spelling|spell]] them are in a continuous change, as we find new ways to communicate. Despite the fact that traditional [[Dictionary|dictionaries]] don't take into account the changes, online ones have adopted many of them.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Misspellings show language's evolution, but does that mean they're OK for journalists to use? {{!}} Poynter.|url = http://www.poynter.org/news/mediawire/161298/misspellings-show-languages-evolution-but-does-that-mean-theyre-ok-for-journalists-to-use/|website = www.poynter.org|accessdate = 2015-10-31}}</ref> An interesting fact outlined in the research above is that communities tend to use their own misspelt words. According to Professor Vincent Jansen from [[Royal Holloway, University of London|Royal Holloway]] communities would misspell words in different ways, just as people have different regional [[Diacritic|accents]].<ref name=":5" /> For example, [[Justin Bieber]] fans tend to end words in ''"ee"'' as in ''"pleasee"'', while school teachers tend to use long words. Moreover, the largest group found in the study was composed of [[African American]]s who were using the words ''"[[nigga]]"'', ''"poppin"'', and ''"chillin"''. Members of this community also had the common habit of shortening the ends of the words, replacing ''"ing"'' with ''"in"'' and ''"er"'' with ''"a"''.<ref name=":4" />
== The campfire == Each tribe has an [[Electronic trading platform|online-platform]] (such as [[Flickr]] or [[Tumblr]]), called campfire around which they gather. These campfires tend to enable one or more of the following three tribal activities:<ref name=":7" /> * [[Cooperation]] (e.g. [[Wikipedia]]) * [[Communication]] (e.g. [[Social network]]s) * [[Cognition]] (e.g. [[Blogs]]) However, some brands are building their own tribes around [[Platforms (computing)|platforms]] outside of these.
== Cooperation == [[Cooperation]] is the action of working together to the same end.<ref>{{Cite web|title = cooperation - definition of cooperation in English from the Oxford dictionary|url = http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/cooperation|website = www.oxforddictionaries.com|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> Cooperation developed naturally over time, as it helped companies to streamline their research costs and to better answer to users' requirements. As a result, nowadays organisations are looking for flexible structures that can easily adapt to this rapidly changing environment. [[Collaborative software|Groupware]] systems perfectly cater to these needs of companies. Informal [[communication]] predominates and specialists in certain domains exchange their experience with other people within the groupware environment. [[Collaboration]] and cooperation are available through instant messages; people can discuss, chat and swap ideas.<ref>{{Cite book|title = Software Applications: Concepts, Methodologies, Tools, and Applications: Concepts, Methodologies, Tools, and Applications|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=_SklFgSidxQC|publisher = IGI Global|date = 2009-03-31|isbn = 9781605660615|first = Tiako, Pierre|last = F}}</ref> Moreover, people can work together while they are located remotely from each other.<ref>{{Cite web|title = What is groupware? - Definition from WhatIs.com|url = http://searchdomino.techtarget.com/definition/groupware|website = SearchDomino|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> Groupware can be split into three categories: '''communication''', '''collaboration''' and '''coordination''', depending on the level of cooperation and technology involved in the process.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Groupware: Communication, Collaboration and Coordination |url=http://www.intranetjournal.com/faq/lotusbible.html |date=2011-07-13 |accessdate=2015-11-01 |deadurl=unfit |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713051554/http://www.intranetjournal.com/faq/lotusbible.html |archivedate=July 13, 2011 }}</ref> One of the biggest and well-known cooperation software is Wikipedia. [[File:Wikipedia-logo-v2-en.svg|thumb|The logo of Wikipedia]]
=== Wikipedia === [[Wikipedia]] is a [[Collaborative real-time editor|collaborative software]] because anyone can edit it. You can edit articles, view past revisions and discuss through a forum the current state of each article. Due to the fact that anyone can change it and find [[information]] very quickly, it has become one of the 10 most accessed sites on the Internet.<ref name=":8" />
==== Advantages ==== Wikipedia has many advantages over other encyclopedias:<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|title = Using the Web to Get Stuff Done: What is Wikipedia?|url = http://www.gcflearnfree.org/using-the-web-to-get-stuff-done/what-is-wikipedia|website = GCFLearnFree.org|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite web|title = The Advantages and Disadvantages Of Using Wikipedia For Research - Youth Village|url = http://www.youthvillage.co.za/2014/10/advantages-disadvantages-using-wikipedia-research/|website = Youth Village|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> * It's free and open for anyone on the Internet; * All past edits and chats from the forum are public and everyone can see them; * Updates happen frequently; * It contains millions of articles; * Easy to use and learn;
==== Disadvantages ==== However, there are also some drawbacks:<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9" /> * Information can be inaccurate; * It is open to [[Spamming|spam]] and [[vandalism]]; * Some articles can contain omissions and be hard to understand; * It can be too open sometimes (for [[Confidentiality|confidential]] documentation); * It requires Internet connectivity.
== Communication == [[Communication]] is the act or an instance of communicating; the imparting or exchange of [[information]], [[idea]]s, or [[feeling]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Definition of "communication" {{!}} Collins English Dictionary|url = http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/communication|website = www.collinsdictionary.com|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> Communication has drastically changed over time and [[social network]]s have changed the way people [[Communication|communicate]].<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.solari.net/documents/position-papers/Solari-Social-Media-and-Communication.pdf|title = Social Media and Its Effect on Communication|date = 2014|accessdate = 1 November 2015|website = http://www.solari.net/|publisher = Solari Communication|last = Maggiani|first = Rich}}</ref> Even though people]can interact with each other 24/7, there is a new wave of barriers and [[threat]]s. In the [[workplace]] environment, electronic Communication has overtaken face-to-face and voice-to-voice Communication by far. This major shift has been done in advantage of [[Millennials|Generation Y]], who prefer [[instant messaging]] than talking directly to someone. It is often said that it could become an ironic twist, but [[social media]] has the real potential of making us less social.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Is Social Media Sabotaging Real Communication?|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/susantardanico/2012/04/30/is-social-media-sabotaging-real-communication/|website = Forbes|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> However, there are studies that confirm that people are becoming more social, but the style in which they interact with each other has changed a lot. One of the major drawbacks of social networks is [[privacy]], as people tend to trust others more rapidly and send more open [[message]]s about themselves. As a result, personal information can be easily exposed to other persons.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Social Media and Interpersonal Communication|url = http://www.socialworktoday.com/archive/051313p10.shtml|website = www.socialworktoday.com|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref> [[Twitter]] and [[Facebook]] are two of the biggest social networks in the world.
=== Facebook === {{essay|section|date=December 2015}} [[Facebook]] is currently the largest social network in the world with more than 1 billion people using this website. This actually means that one in seven people on Earth use Facebook.<ref>{{Cite web|title = From relationships to revolutions: seven ways Facebook has changed the world|url = https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2015/aug/28/from-relationships-to-revolutions-seven-ways-facebook-has-changed-the-world|website = the Guardian|accessdate = 2015-11-01|first = Jessica|last = Elgot}}</ref> Facebook users share their stories, images and videos in order to celebrate and commemorate events together. They can also play [[social network game|social games]] and like other Facebook pages.<ref name=":13" /> Moreover, there is also a section called {{'}}''News Feed''{{'}} where users can see social information from their [[Friendship|friends]] or from the pages that they liked or shared. Each user has their own profile page that is called 'wall', where they can post all the above-mentioned materials (their friends can do this as well).<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url = http://wesscholar.wesleyan.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1008&context=etd_mas_theses|title = The Virtual Campfire: An Ethnography of Online Social Networking|date = May 2008|accessdate = 1 November 2015|website = http://wesscholar.wesleyan.edu/|publisher = Wesleyan University|last = Ryan|first = Jennifer Anne}}</ref> The biggest advantage of Facebook is that you can make new friends, as well as find old [[Interpersonal relationship|acquaintances]] and restart [[Socialization|socialising]] with them. One of the most useful feature of Facebook is the existence of [[Social group|groups]]. Users with the same interests can create a new group or take part in already existing ones to debate information and exchange their ideas. However, there are also groups that are created to declare an affiliation, such as an obsession for different subjects.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Group Dilemma|url = https://www.facebook.com/notes/facebook/the-group-dilemma/2249512130|website = www.facebook.com|accessdate = 2015-11-01}}</ref>
=== Twitter === [[Twitter]] is another social network that allows users to send and read short messages called 'tweets'. Even though messages can contain only 140 characters, this is the perfect length for sending status updates to followers.<ref>{{Cite web|title = New user FAQs|url = https://support.twitter.com/articles/13920|website = Twitter Help Center|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> The main advantage of Twitter is that people can gain followers quickly and share ideas and [[links (web browser)|links]] very fast. There are [[Social network|network]]s of influential people who can be connected via Twitter.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|title = Twitter: Top 5 Ways to Find Your Tribe|url = http://www.thebookdesigner.com/2012/01/twitter-top-5-ways-to-find-your-tribe/|website = The Book Designer|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> On Twitter, tribes manifest themselves as followers of either a person, a company or an institution. As a result, it can be used as a [[marketing]] tool to make someone's [[product (business)|product]] visible, on condition that a big tribe of followers is created. In order to do this, the right community must be built, as finding the right people can be a challenge.<ref>{{Cite web|title = How to Build Your Twitter Tribe|url = http://www.socialmediaexaminer.com/how-to-build-your-twitter-tribe/|website = Social Media Examiner|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> There are some steps that users could take into account in order to make connections and therefore make people follow them: search using Twitter search, follow the followers of other users, look at Twitter Lists, use #[[Hashtag]]s and find [[Third-party developer|third-party]] programs.<ref name=":11" />
== Cognition == [[Cognition]] is the mental action or process of acquiring [[knowledge]] and understanding through [[thought]], [[experience]] and [[sense]]s.<ref>{{Cite web|title = cognition - definition of cognition in English from the Oxford dictionary|url = http://www.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/english/cognition|website = www.oxforddictionaries.com|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> People like to share their ideas and gather together via [[blog]]s. A blog is an online [[Diary|journal]] where people express themselves and want to get their voice heard. People tend to frequent blog communities due to the fact that they offer specific information in which the reader is interested.<ref>{{Cite web|title = What Is a Blog? - Blog Basics|url = http://blogbasics.com/what-is-a-blog/|website = Blog Basics|publisher = https://www.google.com/+Blogbasics|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> There are also [[business]] blogs that can be used to share information within a company. These can be used as a flexible medium, where employees can be informed about topics that can range from the use of new [[technology]] to the company policies.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Help - IBM Connections|url = https://www.ibm.com/developerworks/community/help/index.jsp?topic=%252Fcom.ibm.lotus.connections.blogs.help%252Fc_welcome_blogs.html|website = www.ibm.com|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> On blogs, people tend to gather in tribes or [[clan]]s if they find information that can satisfy their interests. In order to accomplish this goal, bloggers title their postings in such way that they can catch people's attention.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Medical Web Design {{!}} Medical Marketing {{!}} Medical Web Development|url = http://www.mednet-tech.com/newsletter/blogs/what-are-blogs|website = www.mednet-tech.com|accessdate = 2015-11-02}}</ref> The biggest advantage of blogs is that bloggers tend to help each other when someone feels at a loss due to the fact that some bonds might have been created inside the community.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Blog Tip Friday: Create your blogging tribe|url = http://www.honestmom.com/2013/04/05/blog-tip-friday-create-your-blogging-tribe/|website = Honest Mom|accessdate = 2015-11-02|first = Find a Tribe-Kirsten Oliphant|last = says}}</ref>
== Conclusion == As [[Seth Godin]] states, "''The Internet eliminated geography''".<ref name=":7" /> People join tribes or clans because they find and share the same ideas and interests with other people.<ref name=":15" /> The main disadvantage of old tribes is that they couldn't influence group behaviour. On the other hand, new tribes are self-sustaining and can survive without a leader, they are not necessarily dialogue based and they are long lasting. As it has been demonstrated within this article, tribes have influenced the way languages, organisations and cultures work.<ref name=":7" /> They have redefined old concepts with the help of social media and have changed the way people will interact in the future.<ref name=":13" />

[[File:ConstantinoAriasUglyAmerican.jpg|200px|thumb|Constantino Arias' photo titled ''Ugly American'', showing a 1950s [[Fulgencio Batista|Batista]]-era tourist in [[Havana]], [[Cuba]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/12/arts/design/12revolution.html?pagewanted=print Tumult and Triumph in Black and White] by Ken Johnson, ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 11, 2010</ref>]]
"'''Ugly American'''" is a [[pejorative]] term used to refer to perceptions of loud, arrogant, demeaning, thoughtless, ignorant, and [[Ethnocentrism|ethnocentric]] behavior of [[United States|American]] citizens mainly abroad, but also at home.<ref>Richards, Erin (2006). [http://www.cnn.com/2006/TRAVEL/10/31/cultural.etiquette/ ''Are you the ugly American?''] [[CNN]] Travel. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Wederspahn, Gary (2008). [http://www.talesmag.com/tales/practical/ugly_american.shtml ''Avoiding the "Ugly American" Stereotype''] Practical Planet. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Winter, Greg (2004). [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9903E2DE143EF930A1575BC0A9629C8B63 ''Colleges Tell Students the Overseas Party's Over''] [[The New York Times]]. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Clark, Jayne (2006). [https://www.usatoday.com/travel/destinations/2006-04-27-ugly-americans_x.htm ''That 'ugly American' image is getting a makeover guide'']. [[USA Today]]. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Sherwell, Phillip (2007). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2007/03/18/wus18.xml ''Straight-talking McCain vows to fix world's view of the ugly American'']. The [[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Moriarty, Erina (2001). Time Travellers. [http://www.time-travellers.org/Historian/UglyAmerican.html ''How to Avoid Ugly American Syndrome'']. Retrieved on 2 May 2008.</ref> Although the term is usually associated with or applied to travelers and tourists, it also applies to U.S. corporate businesses in the international arena.<ref>Holstein, William (2005). [https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/23/business/yourmoney/23advi.html ''Erasing the Image of the Ugly American'']. [[The New York Times]]. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Gross, Daniel (2007). [http://www.newsweek.com/id/80912 ''Are You an Ugly American?''] [[Newsweek]]. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Clark, Hannah (2006). [https://www.forbes.com/2006/05/19/keith-reinhard-diplomatic-action-cx_hc_0519reinhard.html ''Are You An Ugly American?''] [[Forbes]]. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref><ref>Alban, Debra (2006). [[CNN]]. [http://www.cnn.com/2006/TRAVEL/ADVISOR/08/22/business.etiquette/index.html ''How not to be the ugly American'']. Retrieved on 2 May 2008.</ref><ref>Rosenbaum, Andrew (2002). Harvard Business School, Boston, Mass. [http://hbswk.hbs.edu/archive/3250.html How to Avoid Being the "Ugly American" When Doing Business Abroad]. {{ISBN|1591393485}}. [http://worldcat.org/oclc/52962937 OCLC: 52962937].</ref><ref>Mead, Walter (June 4, 1989). [http://articles.latimes.com/1989-06-04/opinion/op-2358_1_foreign-investment-japan-bashers Japan-Bashing, an Ugly American Tradition]. ''Los Angeles Times''. Retrieved 2011-06-17.</ref>
== Origin == [[Image:The Ugly American poster.jpg|thumb|right|175px|The Ugly American]]
The term was used as the title of a 1948 photograph of an American tourist in Havana by the Cuban photographer Constantino Arias (see infobox above),<ref>Richard P. Horwitz, Ed.,[https://www.webcitation.org/600VsPmQA?url=http://myweb.uiowa.edu/rhorwitz/asacontents.htm The American Studies Anthology]</ref> but seems to have entered popular culture as the title of [[The Ugly American|a 1958 book]] by authors [[William Lederer]] and [[Eugene Burdick]]. In 1963, the book was made into a [[The Ugly American (film)|film]] directed by [[George Englund]] and starring [[Marlon Brando]].
The best-selling, loosely fictional account provided contrasting characters with different approaches to opposing [[Communism|Communist]] influence in [[Southeast Asia]], and the use of [[foreign aid]] in particular. The majority of the Americans exhibit a range of blundering, corrupt, and incompetent behaviors, often concentrating on impractical projects that will serve more to benefit American contractors than the local population. A minority are effective because they employ knowledge of the local language and culture, but most of these are marginalized and some even considered suspect. As a result, their influence is more limited than it should be.<ref>MacArthur, John, R. (2001). [http://www.commondreams.org/views01/1106-01.htm "The Ugly American Mindset"]. ''[[The Globe and Mail|Toronto Globe]]''. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref>
The title character, Homer Atkins, is introduced late in the book. He is "ugly" only in his physical appearance. Perversely, Atkins embodies the opposite traits from the pejorative traits now popularly associated with the term "Ugly American". Atkins' unattractive features, rough clothing and dirty hands are contrasted with the bureaucrats' freshly pressed clothes, clean fingers, and smooth cheeks. Their behaviors have the opposite contrast: Atkins cares about the people of southeast Asia and wants to help them create practical solutions to their everyday problems; the bureaucrats want to build highways and dams that are not yet needed, and with no concern for the many other projects that will have to be completed before they can be used.<ref>{{Cite book |author1=Lederer, William |author2=Burdick, Eugene |lastauthoramp=yes |year=1958 |title=The Ugly American |location=New York |publisher=Norton |oclc=287560|pages=205–209}}</ref> The book led to a move by [[President of the United States|President]] [[Dwight Eisenhower]] to study and reform American aid programs in the region.<ref>Mutual Security Program (1956–57). [http://www.eisenhower.utexas.edu/listofholdingshtml/listofholdingsU/USPRESIDENTSCITIZENADVISORSONTHEMUTUALSECURITYPROGRAMFAIRLESSCOMMITTEERECORDS195657.PDF Dwight D. Eisenhower Library Abilene], [[Kansas]]. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref>
In the book, a fictional [[Myanmar|Burmese]] journalist wrote, "For some reason, the people I meet in my country are not the same as the ones I knew in the United States. A mysterious change seems to come over Americans when they go to a foreign land. They isolate themselves socially. They live pretentiously. They're loud and ostentatious. Perhaps they're frightened and defensive, or maybe they're not properly trained and make mistakes out of ignorance."<ref>Stesney, Julie (2005). [http://www.failuremag.com/arch_arts_uglyamerican_pollyanna_uncletom.html "The Ugly American"]. ''Failure Magazine''. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref>
The idea of the ignorant or badly behaving American traveler long predates this book. [[Mark Twain]] wrote about ''[[The Innocents Abroad]]'' in the nineteenth century, and [[Algonquin Round Table]] member [[Donald Ogden Stewart]] wrote ''Mr and Mrs Haddock Abroad'' in 1924.<ref>Twain, Mark & Cardwell, Guy. [1927](1984). ''The innocents abroad; Roughing it''. New York. {{oclc|10799668}}. {{ISBN|0940450259}}. Retrieved online March 16, 2008.</ref>
==Usage==
===Sports=== The term has also been widely used in the international sporting arena.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1992-08-01/sports/sp-4068_1_olympic-spirit-dream-team-ugly-americans "Who Are the Good, Bad and the Ugly Americans of the Olympics So Far?"] ''Los Angeles Times''. August 1, 1992. Retrieved 2011-06-17.</ref><ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1988-09-24/sports/sp-2180_1_athletes-ugly-americans-los-angeles "Just Call Athletes the Ugly Americans"]. ''Los Angeles Times''. September 24, 1988. Retrieved 2011-06-17.</ref> At the 33rd [[1999 Ryder Cup|Ryder Cup]] held in September 1999, the United States zealously celebrated after [[Justin Leonard]] holed a 45-foot putt on the 17th green, resulting in extensive and adverse media coverage.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1999/oct/02/sports/sp-17870 "Ugly Americans Plus Sour Grapes Equal Bad Whine"] (October 2, 1999). ''Los Angeles Times''. Retrieved 2016-01-22.</ref><ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/sport/1999/sep/27/rydercup2002.rydercup "Joy of victory brings out the ugly American"] (September 27, 1999). ''The Guardian'' (London). Retrieved 2016-01-22.</ref>
Later, at the [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000 Sydney Olympics]], the term was widely used after members of the US [[Athletics at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's 4 × 100 metres relay|4 × 100 relay]] team pranced around the stadium, flexing their muscles and making poses with the American flag, after winning a gold medal.<ref>Ulfelder, Jay (2001). City Paper Online. [http://www.citypaper.com/news/story.asp?id=3534 "Game Face: Is Sportsmanship in the Eye—or the Color—of the Beholder?"] Retrieved on 11 May 2008.</ref> One foreign journalist called the incident "one of the most cringe-making exhibitions that the Olympics has seen".<ref>Sappenfield, Mark (2004). [http://www.csmonitor.com/2004/0805/p01s04-ussc.html "Task for Olympicians: How Not to be the Ugly American"]. ''[[Christian Science Monitor]]''. Retrieved on 2 May 2008.</ref> This event was heavily criticized even by the American press and public. The members of the relay team were contrite and apologized for the incident the same day. Then, at the [[2006 Winter Olympics]] in [[Turin]], the term was regularly used after the skiing superstar [[Bode Miller]], who bragged about skiing drunk before the Olympics, was adversely compared to the term "[[Miller Brewing Company|Miller time]]", and went home with no medals.<ref>NBC Sports (2006). [http://nbcsports.msnbc.com/id/10727859/ "Skiing drunk 'not easy,' Bode says"]. Retrieved online 1 May 2008.</ref> A lesser-known teammate was sent home for fighting in a bar.<ref>Raasch, Chuck (2006). USA Today. [https://www.usatoday.com/news/opinion/columnist/raasch/2006-03-02-raasch_x.htm "Sports, politics tied in Olympic moments"]. Retrieved on 1 May 2008.</ref>
In [[tennis]], the term was used in regard to players at the [[1987 Davis Cup]] for unsportsmanlike conduct.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/1987-08-01/local/me-143_1_drug-investigation The Ugly American Has Taken Up Tennis]. ''Los Angeles Times''. August 1, 1987. Retrieved 2011-06-17.</ref> [[John McEnroe]] was regularly cited in the media as being an "Ugly American" for his on-court tantrums and off-court negative comments about [[London]] and [[Paris]].<ref>Fein, Paul (2005, p. 253). [https://books.google.com/books?id=1XIlvAdMndsC ''You Can Quote Me on That'']. Published by Brassey's. {{OCLC|55679987}}. {{ISBN|1574889257}}</ref> In contrast, [[Andre Agassi]] who early in his tennis career was labeled a "potential ugly American", managed to transform himself into a crowd favourite.<ref>Alfano, Peter (1988). [https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=940DE1DE1F3AF93AA35756C0A96E948260 "Tennis: Ascendant Agassi Wins Tournament"]. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved on 9 November 2008.</ref> In women's tennis, [[Serena Williams]]'s outburst at the [[2009 US Open (tennis)|2009 US Open]] semifinal against [[Kim Clijsters]], and again at the [[2018 US Open (tennis)|2018 tournament]] reiterated the "Ugly American" label.<ref>[http://politicalcenter.newsvine.com/_news/2009/09/13/3260803-the-politics-of-sports-is-serena-williams-career-permanently-marred-by-2009-us-open "The Politics of Sports – Is Serena Williams Career Permanently Marred by 2009 US Open?"] (13 September 2009). NBC Sports: Newsvine.com. Retrieved on 14 September 2009.</ref>
After the [[United States women's national soccer team]] lost to Sweden in the quarterfinals of women's football of the 2016 Summer Olympics in Brazil, [[Hope Solo]] called the Swedish team cowards unleashing multiple Twitter references associating her with this term.<ref>[https://twitter.com/search?q=hope%20solo%20ugly%20american&src=typd] Twitter search: Hope Solo Ugly American</ref><ref>[http://www.desertsun.com/story/sports/columnists/shad-powers/2016/08/12/hope-solo-hammers-home-ugly-american-stereotype/88636902/ Hope Solo hammers home Ugly American stereotype]</ref> At the same Olympics, Gold medalist [[Ryan Lochte]] was named the ugly American by media outlets after falsely reporting a robbery at gunpoint during the tournament. Local police investigation showed that he and fellow swimmers in fact caused damage to a petrol station in Rio and were required to pay for the damage.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ryan Lochte is everything the world hates about Americans|url=https://nypost.com/2016/08/18/ryan-lochte-is-everything-the-world-hates-about-americans/|accessdate=22 August 2016|work=New York Post|date=18 August 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ryan Lochte lied about gunpoint robbery, claim Rio police|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/othersports/article-3747943/USA-swimmer-party-animal-Ryan-Lochte-lied-gunpoint-robbery-claim-Rio-police.html|accessdate=22 August 2016|work=Daily Mail |location=London}}</ref>
===Politics===
The term appeared within a few years of publication of the book ''[[The Ugly American]]''. In 1964, U.S. President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] used it in his [[Great Society]] speech.<ref name="lbj-1964">[[Wikisource:The Great Society]]</ref>
In May 2008, the [[United States House of Representatives|US House sub-committee]] passed a [[Bill (proposed law)|bill]] (House Resolution 4080) that would allow more [[Alien (law)|foreign]] [[Model (person)|fashion models]] to work in the United States, and was subsequently dubbed the "ugly American bill".<ref>Russ, Dick (2008). [http://www.wkyc.com/news/news_article.aspx?storyid=89177 ''Ugly American' bill passes committee; allows more foreign models to work in U.S.''] WKYC Cleveland. Retrieved on 25 September 2008.</ref> George W. Bush was often referred to as "The Ugly American" in part because of his stance on [[foreign policies]].<ref>Debusmann, Bernd (2008). [http://www.iht.com/articles/2008/11/13/america/letter.php Obama and a makeover for the 'ugly American']. [[International Herald Tribune]]. Retrieved on 1 January 2009.</ref><ref>Walt, Vivienne (2003). [https://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2003-02-13-france-usat_x.htm ''French see Bush as the ugly American'']. ''[[USA Today]]''. Retrieved on 1 January 2009.</ref><ref>Berrigan, Frida (2003). [http://www.fpif.org/commentary/0102colombia.html The "Ugly American Problem" in Colombia]. ''Foreign Policy in Focus''. Retrieved on 1 January 2009.</ref><ref>LeBoutillier, John (2003). [http://archive.newsmax.com/archives/articles/2003/3/10/122938.shtml ''The New Ugly American'']. Newsmax. Retrieved on 1 January 2009.</ref> In 2007, [[President of the United States|Presidential]] hopeful [[John McCain]] outlined a series of measures to roll back Bush policies and counter the "ugly American" image.<ref>Sherwell, Philip (18 March 2007). [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/1545925/Straight-talking-McCain-vows-to-fix-worlds-view-of-the-ugly-American.html Straight-talking McCain vows to fix world's view of the 'ugly American']. The Telegraph. Retrieved 2011-06-11.</ref>
===Popular culture=== The "ugly American" tourist stereotype has been heavily depicted in films, with characters such as [[List of James Bond allies#Sheriff J.W. Pepper|Sheriff J.W. Pepper]] in ''[[The Man with the Golden Gun (film)|The Man with the Golden Gun]]'',<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/apr/15/clifton-james-actor-sheriff-jw-pepper-james-bond-dies |title=Clifton James, actor who played Sheriff JW Pepper in Bond films, dies at 96 |publisher=''[[The Guardian]]'' |date=15 April 2017 |accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> the Griswald family in ''[[National Lampoon's European Vacation]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.dvdmg.com/europeanvacation.shtml |title=''National Lampoon's European Vacation'' |publisher=DVD Movie Guide |accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://lhsroar.com/opinions/ugly-americans/ |title=Ugly Americans |author=Bagwell, Ashley |publisher=[[Leander High School]] |date=15 January 2009 |accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref> and Ralph Jones in ''[[King Ralph]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/zip-it-621118 |title=Zip It |author=Ward, Victoria |publisher=''[[Daily Mirror]]'' |date=17 April 2006 |accessdate=10 November 2017}}</ref>
The 2004 film ''[[EuroTrip]]'' was originally slated to be named "The Ugly Americans" due to its depiction of stereotypical American tourists in Europe.<ref>Mitchell, Elvis (2004). [https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/296452/Eurotrip/overview Eurotrip (2004)]. The New York Times: Movies. Retrieved on 18 September 2009.</ref> The producers changed the title shortly before its release.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/collective/A1980362 Hollywood gets ugly] (7 November 2003). [[BBC]]: Collective. Retrieved on 18 September 2009.</ref>
A study carried out in 2002 revealed that [[Hollywood]] also contributes to the "Ugly American" image. The study found that the more access other countries had to American programs, the higher their negative attitudes toward Americans tended to be.<ref>[http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jan/21/opinion/oe-gingrich21 We Can Thank Hollywood for Our Ugly-American Image]. Los Angeles Times. January 21, 2003. Retrieved 2011-06-17.</ref>
The movie ''[[Sex and the City 2]]'' has been quoted as a typical portrayal of the "ugly American" image, where Samantha, one of four best girlfriends, makes fun of [[Middle East]]ern culture and women in traditional dress.<ref>Kelly, Christopher (June 20, 2011). [http://events.charlotteobserver.com/reviews/show/266945-review-sex-and-the-city-2 'City 2' heroines come across as ugly Americans]. The Charlotte Observer. Retrieved 2011-06-20.</ref>
''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode "[[The Regina Monologues]]" had the Simpson family getting into all sorts of trouble in England.

revision.comment: Clarification of Gunter Pauli's book 'Upsizing' and its subsequent retitling
revision.text:
{{lead rewrite|date=April 2018}} '''Upcycling''', also known as '''creative reuse''', is the process of transforming by-products, waste materials, useless, or unwanted products into new materials or products of better quality or for better environmental value. Upcycling is the opposite of [[downcycling]], which is the other face of the [[recycling]] process. Downcycling involves converting materials and products into new materials of lesser quality. Most recycling involves converting or extracting useful materials from a product and creating a different product or material.{{cite web | title=Recycling| url=http://blumarble.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/05/Recycling.pdf| website=Environmental Protection Agency| accessdate=2015-05-14}} The term ''downcycling'' was first used in print in an article in SalvoNEWS by Thornton Kay quoting Reiner Pilz and published in 1994. [https://www.salvoweb.com/files/sn99sm24y94tk181119.pdf Thornton Kay, Salvo in Germany - Reiner Pilz, p14 SalvoNEWS No99 11 October 1994] {{quote|We talked about the impending EU Demolition Waste Streams directive. "Recycling," he said, "I call it downcycling. They smash bricks, they smash everything. What we need is upcycling, where old products are given more value, not less." He despairs of the German situation and recalls the supply of a large quantity of reclaimed woodblock from an English supplier for a contract in Nuremberg, while just down the road a load of similar block was scrapped. In the road outside his premises was the result of the Germans' demolition "waste" recycling. It was a pinky looking aggregate with pieces of handmade brick, old tiles, and discernible parts of useful old items mixed with crushed concrete. Is this the future for Europe?}} ''Upsizing'' was the title of the German edition of a book about upcycling first published in English in 1998 by [[Gunter Pauli]] and given the revised title of ''Upcycling'' in 1999. The German edition was adapted to the German language and culture by Johannes F. Hartkemeyer, then Director of the [[Volkshochschule]] in [[Osnabrück]]. The concept was later incorporated by [[William McDonough]] and [[Michael Braungart]] in their 2002 book ''[[Cradle to Cradle: Remaking the Way We Make Things]]''. They state that the goal of upcycling is to prevent wasting potentially useful materials by making use of existing ones. This reduces the consumption of new [[raw materials]] when creating new products. Reducing the use of new raw materials can result in a reduction of energy usage, [[air pollution]], [[water pollution]] and even [[greenhouse gas]] emissions. This is a significant step towards regenerative design culture where the end products are cleaner, healthier, and usually have a better value than the material inputs. For example, during the recycling process of plastics other than those used to create bottles, many different types of plastics are mixed, resulting in a hybrid. This hybrid is used in the manufacturing of plastic lumber applications. However, unlike the engineered polymer ABS which hold properties of several plastics well, recycled plastics suffer phase-separation that causes structural weakness in the final product. In 2009, Belinda Smith from Reuters wrote that upcycling had increased in the rich countries but observed that upcycling was a necessity in poorer ones:
Supporters of the [[environmentally friendly]] practice of upcycling say people in developing countries have effectively been upcycling for years, using old packaging and clothing in new ways, although more out of need than for the environment. But upcycling is now taking off in other countries, reflecting an increased interest in [[Sustainable products|eco-friendly products]], particularly ones that are priced at an affordable level and proving profitable for the manufacturers. "If upcycling is going to become mainstream, then the corporate world needs to see that it can be profitable," said Albe Zakes, spokesman of U.S. company TerraCycle which specializes in finding new uses for discarded packaging. A growing number of companies are focusing on upcycling although the trend is still in its infancy with industry-wide figures yet to be produced.{{cite web|last=Goldsmith|first=Belinda|date=2009-09-30|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/smallBusinessNews/idUSTRE58T3HX20090930|title=Trash or Treasure? Upcycling Becomes Growing Green Trend|publisher=[[Reuters]]|accessdate=2009-12-02}}
Upcycling has shown significant growth across the United States. For example, the number of products on [[Etsy]] or [[Pinterest]] tagged with the word "upcycled" increased from about 7,900 in January 2010 to nearly 30,000 a year later—an increase of 275%.{{cite web|url=http://www.entrepreneur.com/article/219310 |title=Upcycling Becomes a Treasure Trove for Green Business Ideas |website=[[Entrepreneur Magazine]] |date=March 22, 2011 |accessdate=2013-05-14}} {{As of|2013|04}}, that number stood at 263,685, an additional increase of 879%.{{cite web|url=http://www.southernminn.com/faribault_daily_news/news/article_a8276afa-e288-50f3-8573-203e788f9366.html|title=Upcycle trend hits Faribault area|website=Southernminn.com}} Material [[downcycling]] occurs when it is not economic to restore materials to their original quality, for example, when wrought aluminium alloys are melted to produce lower-grade casting alloys.{{Cite journal|last=Cullen|first=Jonathan|date=2017|title=Circular Economy: Theoretical Benchmark or Perpetual Motion Machine?|journal=Journal of Industrial Ecology|volume=21|issue=3|pages=483–486|doi=10.1111/jiec.12599}} Material ''upcycling'', in the thermodynamic sense, is only possible if even more energy is added to upgrade the material quality. Two guiding questions to ask when assessing recovering for waste materials or products are: How much energy is required to restore the recovered material back to the desired material or product?, and, How does this quantity compare with obtaining the desired material or product from virgin or primary sources? In some cases, little energy is required to reuse a discarded product, for example, secondhand clothing. In other cases, the energy required to recover the materials is more than the energy required to process virgin material. In the last case, ''upcycling'' may be considered worst for environmental emissions strategies if energy comes from fossil fuels. == In art == [[File:Vorwarts! (Go Forward!), 1897 F.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Johann Dieter Wassmann (Jeff Wassmann), ''Vorwarts! (Go Forward!)'', 1897]] [[File:צעצוע נגרר דרום הר חברון.jpg|thumb|A toy from Southern [[Mount Hebron]], on loan to [[Israel Museum]] from a private collection]] The tradition of reusing [[found objects]] (''objet trouvé'') in mainstream art came of age sporadically through the 20th century, although it has long been a means of production in [[folk art]]. The [[Amish]] [[quilt]], for example, came about through reapplication of salvaged fabric. [[Simon Rodia]]'s [[Watts Towers]] (1921–1954) in [[Los Angeles]] exemplifies upcycling of scrap metal, pottery and broken glass on a grand scale; it consists of 17 structures, the tallest reaching over 30 meters into the [[Watts, Los Angeles|Watts]] skyline. Intellectually, upcycling bears some resemblance to the [[Readymades of Marcel Duchamp|ready-made]] art of [[Marcel Duchamp]] and the [[Dadaists]]. Duchamp's "[[Bicycle Wheel]]" (1913), a front wheel and fork attached to a common stool, is among the earliest of these works, while "[[Fountain (Duchamp)|Fountain]]" (1917), a common urinal purchased at a hardware store, is arguably his best-known work. Pablo Picasso's "[[Bull's Head]]" (1942), a sculpture made from a discarded bicycle saddle and handlebars, is the Spanish painter's sly nod to the Dadaists.Gibson, Eric, [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703551304576261042931202326 "A Magical Metamorphosis of the Ordinary"], ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'', April 16, 2011. Throughout the mid-century the artist [[Joseph Cornell]] fabricated collages and boxed [[Assemblage (art)|assemblage]] works from old books, found objects and [[ephemera]]. [[Robert Rauschenberg]] collected trash and disused objects, first in Morocco and later on the streets of New York, to incorporate into his art works. The idea of consciously raising the inherent value of recycled objects as a political statement, however, rather than presenting recycled objects as a reflection or outcome from the means of production, is largely a late 20th century concept. [[Romuald Hazoumé]], an artist from the [[West Africa]]n [[Bénin]], was heralded in 2007 for his use of discarded plastic gasoline and fuel canisters to resemble traditional African masks at [[Documenta]] 12 in [[Kassel]], [[Germany]]. Hazoumé has said of these works, "I send back to the West that which belongs to them, that is to say, the refuse of consumer society that invades us every day."{{cite web|url=http://www.caacart.com/pigozzi-artist.php?i=Hazoume-Romuald&m=35|title=Romuald Hazoumé|website=Contemporary African Art Collection – The Pigozzi Collection}} [[Jeff Wassmann]], an American artist who has lived in Australia for the past 25 years, uses items found on beaches and junk stores in his travels to create the early Modern works of a fictional German relative, [[Johann Dieter Wassmann]] (1841–1898). In "''Vorwarts'' (Go Forward)" (pictured), Wassmann uses four simple objects to depict a vision of modern man on the precarious eave of the 20th century: an early optometry chart as background, a [[clock spring]] as eye, a 19th-century Chinese bone opium spoon from the Australian gold fields as nose and an upper set of [[dentures]] found on an Australian beach as mouth. Wassmann is unusual among artists in that he does not sell his work, rather they are presented as gifts; by not allowing these works to re-enter the consumer cycle, he averts the [[commodification]] of his end product.Crawford, Ashley, [http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/10/09/1065676092105.html "Hoax Most Perfect"], ''The Age'', October 11, 2003. [[Max Zorn (artist)|Max Zorn]] is a Dutch tape artist who creates artwork from ordinary brown packaging tape and hangs pieces on street lamps as a new form of [[street art]] at night. By adding and subtracting layers of tape on [[acrylic glass]] with a surgical scalpel, the artwork can only be visible when light is placed behind it, mimicking the effects similar to [[stained glass]] window methods. His technique with pioneering upcycling with street art has been featured at Frei-Cycle 2013, the first design fair for recycling and upcycling in [[Freiburg]], Germany.{{cite web|title=Designmesse für Recycling & Upcycling|url=http://frei-cycle.de/|accessdate=29 October 2013}} {{clear left}} == In music == A prominent example is the [[Recycled Orchestra of Cateura]] in [[Paraguay]], created in 2006 by the program '''[http://www.sonidosdelatierra.org.py/ Sounds of the Earth]''', directed by [[Luis Szaran]]. The instruments of the orchestra are made from materials taken from the landfill of [[Asunción]], whose name comes from the [[Cateura]] lagoon in the area. A limited part of its real history is narrated in the film "[[Landfill Harmonic]]", according to the version of [[Favio Chavez]], ex-coordinator of "Sounds of the Earth"{{cite news |last= Tsioulcas |first= Anastasia | authorlink= |title= From Trash To Triumph: The Recycled Orchestra|url= https://www.npr.org/sections/deceptivecadence/2016/09/14/493794763/from-trash-to-triumph-the-recycled-orchestra| date= 14 September 2016|work= [[NPR]] |location=Washington, D. C. | accessdate= 31 January 2017 }}{{cite web |url= http://www.classicfm.com/artists/landfill-harmonic/pictures/landfill-harmonic-orchestra-pictures/|title= Landfill Harmonic: The Recycled Orchestra: making music on a landfill site |author= |date= |website= www.classicfm.com |publisher= | accessdate= 31 January 2017 }}. In May 2016, an original member of the orchestra {{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.py/2017/02/12/se-enaltece-la-bandera-del-pais-tema-precio|title=Se enaltece la bandera del país, pero el tema es a qué precio|publisher=}} and two members of the parents' association{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.py/espectaculo_edicion_impresa/2017/04/02/tesorera-de-armonia-de-cateura-da-su-version-sobre-la-orquesta|title=Tesorera de "Armonía de Cateura" da su versión sobre la Orquesta|publisher=}}, who helped build the current building of the Cateura music school{{cite web|url=https://genrising.org/2015/03/03/construction-begins-on-community-education-centre/|title=Construction begins on Community Education Centre – Generation Rising|website=genrising.org}}; filed a complaint with the Office of the Prosecutor against the director's administration{{cite web|url=http://www.ultimahora.com/chavez-fondos-la-orquesta-van-mi-cuenta-y-no-mi-bolsillo-n1062965.html|title=Chávez: "Fondos para la orquesta van a mi cuenta y no a mi bolsillo"|publisher=}}, for alleged lack of transparency. The complaint is backed by three senators from Paraguay{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.py/2017/02/15/fiscal-tomo-declaraciones-caso-reciclados/|title=Fiscal tomó declaraciones sobre caso Reciclados|publisher=}}. == In industry == Many industrial processes, like plastic and electronic fabrication, rely on the consumption of finite resources.Martin, M. and Parsapour, A. 2012. "Upcycling wastes with biogas production : An exergy and economic analysis". Venice 2012: International Symposium on Energy from Biomass and Waste (2012).Zhuo, C. and Levendis, Y. A. 2014. "Upcycling waste plastics into carbon nanomaterials: A review". ''Journal of Applied Polymer Science''. 131, 4 (2014) Furthermore, the waste may have an environmental impact and can affect human health. Within this context, upcycling describes the use of available and future technologies to reduce waste and [[resource consumption]] by creating a product with a higher value from waste or byproduct streams. INDUSTRIAL UPCYCLING is new complex methodology for waste prevention. In late 2015 on logistics conference LOGISTICS RIDE, Ostrava, Czech Republic, it was named for the first time INDUSTRY 5.0. It consist of tools and methods streamlining the production surplus from one process or factory to next one. The originator of the complex methodology is Michael Rada, who started successful implementation within Czech republic industrial environment and expand to other locations.{{cite conference|last1=Sung|first1=K.|last2=Cooper|first2=T.|last3=Kettley|first3=S.|date=2014|title=Individual Upcycling Practice: Exploring the Possible Determinants of Upcycling Based on a Literature Review|location=Copenhagen|conference=Sustainable Innovation 2014 Conference}} In consumer electronics, the process of re-manufacturing or [[Refurbishment (electronics)|refurbishment]] of second-hand products can be seen as upcycling because of the reduced energy and material consumption in contrast to new manufacturing. The re-manufactured product has a higher value than disposing or downcycling it.Steinhilper, R. and Hieber, M. 2001. "Remanufacturing-the key solution for transforming downcycling into upcycling of electronics". ''Electronics and the Environment'', 2001. Proceedings of the 2001 IEEE International Symposium on (2001), 161–166. The use of [[Brewer's spent grain]], a waste product of [[brewing]] processes, as a [[Substrate (chemistry)|substrate]] in [[biogas]] processes eliminates the need for disposal and can generate significant profit to the overall brewing process. Depending on the substrate's price, a profit of approximately 20% of the operational costs is possible. In this process, the biogas plant acts as an "upcycler". == In libraries == [[File:Upcycled Roses.jpg|thumb|Roses made from upcycled library books.]] As libraries are becoming more than just bricks, mortar and their collections, modern librarians are increasing their programming efforts. Upcycle programs or classes/clubs are becoming more and more popular, especially with the help of [[Pinterest]]. The Titusville Public Library has an upcycle class that started out by making roses. An organization called ScrapDC[http://scrapdc.org/about/what-we-are/ About ScrapDC]{{dead link|date=August 2018}} led Upcycle classes at the [[District of Columbia Public Library]], more specifically their [[Southeast Neighborhood Library]]. One of their more popular projects was turning old books into boxes.{{cite web|url=https://www.dclibrary.org/node/45020|title=Books, Upcycling, and 3-D Printing: Crafting for the Modern Age!|date=10 October 2014|publisher=}} The [[Jerry Falwell Library]] at [[Liberty University]] holds an annual Creative Upcycling Contest for their students. The first contest had 44 submissions of “Art Made from Books”. These submissions were three-dimensional upcycles.{{cite web|url=http://www.liberty.edu/news/index.cfm?PID=18495&MID=131771|title=Students transform books into 3D art in library upcycling contest – Liberty University|website=www.liberty.edu}} == With food == Billions of pounds of food are wasted every year around the world, but there are good ways that people reuse the food and find a way to upcycle. A way that is used very often is to feed it to animals because a lot of animals, such as a pig, will eat all the scraps given. Food waste can be donated and restaurants can save all the food customers don't eat. Donations can also be made by contacting local agricultural extension offices to find out where to donate food waste and telling them how often and how much you can donate.{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/sustainable-management-food/reduce-wasted-food-feeding-animals|title=Reduce wasted food by feeding animals|website=epa.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Another form of upcycling food would be to break it down and use it as energy. Engineers have found a way to break the food down into a reusable bio-fuel by pressure cooking it and then they are able to make methane out of the remains which can be used to produce a lot of electricity and heat.{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/sustainable-management-food/industrial-uses-wasted-food|title=Industrial uses for wasted food|website=epa.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} When the food isn't used in those ways, another way is to just break it down and use it in compost, which will improve the soil. Pretty much any type of food waste, such as fruits, vegetables, egg shells, nuts, and nut shells, can be used in compost to make it richer soil.{{Cite web|url=https://www.epa.gov/sustainable-management-food/reducing-impact-wasted-food-feeding-soil-and-composting|title=reducing the impact of wasted food by feeding the soil and composting|website=epa.gov|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} == In design processes == Tonnes of wastes are produced every day in our cities, and some educators are attempting to raise citizens' awareness, especially the youth. To redefine the concept of recycling previously confined to trash categorization, groups of young designers have attempted to transform "trash" into potentially marketable products such as backpacks made of waste plastic bags{{Cite web|url=https://www.up-fuse.com/|title=Up-Fuse}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.kubrick.com.hk/index.php/zh_hk/9789889891329.html|title=Kubrick Web Shop}} and area rugs created by reusing hides{{Cite web|url=https://upcyclerefinery.com/about/|title=What We Do – Upcycle Refinery|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. One relevant book published by Community Museum Project in [[Hong Kong]] in 2010, was the first experiment on upcycling systems design. Spanning across material collecting, upcycling design, local production and public dissemination, it provides proposals towards a sustainable system that will cast impact on our strategies of waste handling and energy saving.{{Cite web|url=http://hk.apple.nextmedia.com/supplement/culture/art/20130323/18204240|title=升級再造3：廢物‧迷思|website=Apple Daily 蘋果日報|access-date=2016-03-23}} Hong Kong local inventor [[Gary Chan (inventor)|Gary Chan]] is actively involved in designing and making 'upcycling' bikes by making use of waste materials as parts for his bikes. He invented at least 8 bikes using wastes as a majority of the materials.{{Cite web|url=http://www.metropop.com.hk/contents/425/green/1484/|title=土炮發明王|date=2014-10-16|website=www.metropop.com.hk|language=zh-HK|access-date=2016-03-23}}{{Cite web|url=http://yp.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/article/92828/gary-chan-bad-boy-bicycle-building-hong-kong|title=Gary Chan is the bad boy of bicycle building in Hong Kong|website=Young Post {{!}} South China Morning Post|access-date=2016-03-23}} Gary and his partners at Wheel Thing Makers regularly collect useful wastes such as leather skin from sofas, hardwood plates of wardrobes, or rubber tires from vehicle repair stores in the waste collection station on streets.{{Cite web|url=https://eweekly.hk/article/_title/%25E8%25BD%2586%25E8%25BD%2586%25E7%2584%25A1%25E7%25AA%25AE_kpdo78smj3|title=E Media+ {{!}} E週刊 {{!}} e+娛樂 {{!}} Mode {{!}} 美食旅客|website=eweekly.hk|access-date=2016-03-23}} Similar concepts evolve allover the world to tackle issue of rising excess of waste through creation of [[Circular economy|circular economies]] within the communities. == Potential technologies and applications == The worldwide plastic production was 280 million tons in 2011 and production levels are growing every year. Its haphazard disposal causes severe environmental damage such as the creation of the [[Great Pacific garbage patch]]. In order to solve this problem, the employment of modern technologies and processes to reuse the waste plastic as a cheap substrate is under research. The goal is to bring this material from the waste stream back into the mainstream by developing processes which will create an economic demand for them. One approach in the field involves the conversion of waste plastics (like [[LDPE]], [[Polyethylene terephthalate|PET]], and [[HDPE]]) into [[paramagnetic]], conducting microspheresMondal, M., Gohs, U., Wagenknecht, U. and Heinrich, G. 2013. "Polypropylene/natural rubber thermoplastic vulcanizates by eco-friendly and sustainable electron induced reactive processing". ''Radiation Physics and Chemistry''. 88, 0 (2013), 74–81. or into carbon nanomaterials by applying high temperatures and [[chemical vapor deposition]].Tariq Altalhi, Tushar Kumeria, Abel Santos, Dusan Losic, [https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.carbon.2013.07.003 "Synthesis of well-organised carbon nanotube membranes from non-degradable plastic bags with tuneable molecular transport: Towards nanotechnological recycling"], ''Carbon'', Volume 63, November 2013, pp. 423-433, {{ISSN|0008-6223}} On a molecular level, the treatment of [[polymers]] like [[polypropylene]] or [[thermoplastics]] with [[electron beam]]s (doses around 150 [[gray (unit)|kGy]]) can increase material properties like [[bending strength]] and [[elasticity (physics)|elasticity]] and provides an eco-friendly and [[sustainable]] way to upcycle them.Czvikovszky, T. and Hargitai, H. 1997. "Electron beam surface modifications in reinforcing and recycling of polymers. Nuclear Instruments and Methods" in ''Physics Research Section B: Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms''. 131, 1–4 (1997), 300–304. Active research is being carried out for the [[biotransformation]] upcycling of plastic waste (e.g., [[polyethylene terephthalate]] and [[polyurethane]]) into [[Polyhydroxyalkanoates|PHA]] [[bioplastic]] using bacteria.{{Cite web|url=http://www.p4sb.eu/|title=Homepage – P4SB|website=www.p4sb.eu|language=en|access-date=2017-10-26}} PET could be converted into the biodegradable [[Polyhydroxyalkanoates|PHA]] by using a combination of temperature and microbial treatment. First it gets [[pyrolysis|pyrolized]] at 450 °C and the resulting [[terephthalic acid]] is used as a substrate for microorganisms, which convert it finally into PHA.Kenny, S.T., Runic, J.N., Kaminsky, W., Woods, T., Babu, R.P., Keely, C.M., Blau, W. and O’Connor, K.E. 2008. "Up-Cycling of PET (Polyethylene Terephthalate) to the Biodegradable Plastic PHA (Polyhydroxyalkanoate)". ''Environmental Science & Technology''. 42, 20 (2008), 7696–7701. Similar to the aforementioned approach is the combination of nanomaterials like carbon nanotubes with powdered orange peel as a composite material. This might be used to remove synthetic [[dye]]s from [[wastewater]].Jain, N., Basniwal, R. K., Suman, Srivastava, A. K., & Jain, V. K. (2010). "Reusable nanomaterial and plant biomass composites for the removal of methylene blue from water", ''Environmental Technology'', 31(7), 755-760. [[Biotechnology]] companies have recently shifted focus towards the conversion of agricultural waste, or [[biomass]], to different chemicals or commodities. One company in particular, [[BioTork]], has signed an agreement with the State of Hawaii and the [[USDA]] to convert the unmarketable papayas in Hawaii into [[fish feed]]. As part of this Zero Waste Initiative put forth by the State of Hawaii, BioTork will upcycle the otherwise wasted biomass into a high quality, omega-rich fish feed.{{cite web|url=http://domesticfuel.com/2014/08/07/hawaii-funds-biotork-advanced-biofuel-technology/|title=Hawaii Funds BioTork Advanced Biofuel Technology|website=Domestic Fuel}} == Clothes == Designers have begun to use both industrial textile waste and existing clothing as base material for creating new fashions. Upcycling has been known to use either pre-consumer or post-consumer waste or possibly a combination of the two. Pre-consumer waste is made while in the factory, such as fabric remnants left over from cutting out patterns. post-consumer waste refers to the finished product when it’s no longer useful to the owner, such as donated clothes {{cite web|url=https://www.triplepundit.com/special/sustainable-fashion-2014/upcycling-new-wave-sustainable-fashion/|title=Upcycling: The New Wave of Sustainable Fashion|date=May 8, 2014|author= Beth Stewart}}. Often, we practice linear economy where we are content to buy, use then throw away. This system contributes to millions of kilos of textile waste being thrown away and makes fashion is the second-most polluting industry after oil {{cite web|url=https://textilebeat.com/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/Global-apparel-fibre-consumption-vs-population-FINAL.jpg|title=Global-apparel-fibre-consumption-vs-population-FINAL.jpg}}. while most textiles produced are recyclable, around 85% end-up in landﬁlls in the USA alone {{cite journal |last1=Weber |first1=Sabine |last2=Lynes |first2=Jennifer |last3=Young |first3=Steven B. |title=Fashion interest as a driver for consumer textile waste management: reuse, recycle or disposal |journal=International Journal of Consumer Studies |date=March 2017 |volume=41 |issue=2 |pages=207–215 |doi=10.1111/ijcs.12328}}. Fast fashion companies are huge contributors to these problems as their whole purpose is to mass produce cheap clothing. To live a sustainable life we need other clothing options that demonstrates the opposite to the throw away attitude fast fashion has lead us to. Upcycling can help us with this as it puts into practice a more circular economy model. A Circular Economy is where resources are used for as long as possible, getting the most value out of them while in use, then restored and repurposed when their use is over. Popularized by McDonough and Braungart’s this has also been known as the cradle-to-cradle principle. This principle states a product should be designed either to have multiple life cycles or be biodegradable {{cite journal|url=https://link-springer-com.ezproxy.flinders.edu.au/content/pdf/10.1007/978-3-319-51253-2.pdf|title=Sustainability in Fashion|editor=Claudia E. Henninger|editor2=Panayiota J. Alevizou|editor3=Helen Goworek|editor4=Daniella Ryding|date=|website=flinders.edu.au|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-51253-2}}. Not only does upcycling help environmentally but there are also economic benefits. By reusing materials that others may not find as desirable there are huge savings that can be made on buying supplies for business or personal use. At schools or university upcycling for art, craft and design can be an easy and cheap way to prototype or finish a student project. The can also be an economic benefit with the final product. By it definition upcycling means increasing value to the original product and this can be done by changing/adding your own spin to the design or improving material quality or fixing broken clothes. == See also == {{Portal|Sustainable development|Environment}} {{Wiktionary|upcycle|upcycling}} * [[Environmentalism]] * [[Jury rig]] * [[Looptworks]] * [[Modding]] * [[Reuse]] * [[Scrapstore]] * [[Trashion]] * [[Waste hierarchy]] * [[Food rescue]] == References == {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Recycling}} {{Waste}} [[Category:Culture and the environment]] [[Category:Handicrafts]] [[Category:Recycling]] [[Category:Reuse]]

'''Wodani people''' | image = | caption = | population = 6,920{{cite web|url=http://joshuaproject.net/people_groups/15404/ID |title=Wolani in Indonesia |publisher=[[Joshua Project]] |accessdate=2014-09-18}} | popplace = {{flag|Indonesia}} ([[Papua (province)]]) | langs = [[Wolani language]], [[Indonesian language]] | rels = [[Animism]] (predominantly), [[Christianity]] | related = [[Ekari people]], [[Moni people]] }} The '''Wolani''' or '''Wodani''' are a people in the Indonesian [[Paniai Regency|Paniai regency]] (kabupaten) of the [[Papua (province)|Papua province]] (formerly Central Irian Jaya) of [[West Papua (region)|West Papua]] (western part of the island of [[New Guinea]]). Numbering about 5000 in 1992, they are farmers who live in the central highlands northeast of [[Lake Paniai]], along the Kemandoga and Mbiyandogo rivers. Many Wolani converted to [[Christianity]] but, like elsewhere in Indonesia, they retain their traditional religion. They speak [[Wolani language|Wolani]], which is affiliated with the western branch of the [[Trans–New Guinea languages]],{{Ethnologue20|wod|Wolani}} similar to the nearby [[Ekari language|Ekari]] and [[Moni language|Moni]] languages. It is not clear if the Wolani are a subgroup of the [[Lani people|Lani]]. There is some imprecision in the classification of cultures in this region, with the [[Lani people|Lani]] often being identified with a larger group, the [[Dani people|Dani]]. == Representations in Media == * ''The Wolani Shells'' is a 2005 film by British filmmaker Alastair Kenneil.{{Citation|last=Kenneil|first=Alastair|title=The Wolani|date=2005-03-10|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1787925/|accessdate=2018-04-17}} In 2005, National Geographic aired the film as ''Tribal Odyssey: the Wolani Shells'' (Season 1, Episode 2 of its Tribal Odyssey series).{{Cite web|url=https://www.thetvdb.com/?tab=episode&seriesid=257830&seasonid=489308&id=4299447&lid=7|title=Tribal Odyssey: The Wolani, West Papua|website=www.thetvdb.com|access-date=2018-04-17}} * A Wolani song, ''Troisième soirée, Les Wolani à Ebugangwe - Yohi-Yaya-O, calme'', appears in a collection of regional music, ''Les Dani de Nouvelle Guinée Volume 1''. == See also == * [[Stéphane Breton (filmmaker)]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Papuan ethnic groups}} {{Ethnic groups in Indonesia}} {{Portal|Indonesia}} [[Category:Ethnic groups in Indonesia]] [[Category:Indigenous ethnic groups in Western New Guinea]] {{Indonesia-stub}}

In Pre-Islamic [[Arabian mythology]], '''Zarqa’ al-Yamama''' ({{lang-ar|{{Large|زرقاء اليمامة}}}}) was a blue-eyed woman with exceptional intuition, keen sight, and ability to predict events before they happened. Some Arab historians argue that the district of [[Al-Yamama]] was named after her.
==Zarqa al-Yamama’s legend== According to the ancient tale, Zarqa’s tribe relied on her powers in detecting enemies and defending their land; as she was believed to have the ability to see riders from the distance of one week. In hopes to evade Zarqa’s gaze, enemies of her tribe decided to hide behind trees which they carried. Zarqa noticed what was going on and alerted her tribe that the trees were moving towards them and that they hid soldiers behind them. To her dismay, members of her tribe thought she was going mad and choose to ignore her warning . The troops of [[Hassan Ibn Tubba' As'ad Abi Karib|Hassan al-Himyari]] eventually reached her tribe and killed every man in the camp, then they tore out Zarqa’s eyes and crucified her.
